In Hmong, adverbs do not exist. Instead, two adjectives or two verbs are used (e.g., I ran fast fast to the store). In Spanish, Arabic, Farsi, Vietnamese, and Hmong, adjectives follow the nouns they modify (instead of before the noun, as in English).

Practice articulation with a few simple sentences containing adjectives and adverbs, such as: The happy dog wagged its tail. and I ran quickly. Then have students copy the sentences to practice writing the sentences in correct English word order.

Remind students that end punctuation can help readers tell what kind of sentence they are reading.
Review the kind of sentences that end with a period, question mark, and an exclamation point. Have students compare the end punctuation for sentences 13.
Then discuss the different types of punctuation:
The question mark shows that the sentence is a question. The exclamation point shows that the sentence shows excitement. The period shows that the sentence is a statement.

Add -ly to loud. Model for students how to read the new word.
Explain that the word loud is an adjective that describes a noun. The suffix -ly changes loud to loudly, which is an adverb, a word that describes an adjective or verb.
Provide and discuss two sentences that show how the words loud and loudly differ: The alarm is loud. The alarm rings loudly.
Repeat the procedure by adding the suffix -y to wind.
Explain that the word wind is a noun. The suffix -y changes the word wind to an adjective.
Provide and discuss two sentences that show how the words wind and windy differ: The wind blows. It is a windy day.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
This is the /a/ square. Add a square to show me at.
Students should add a different color square after the purple /a/ square. Say:
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /a/ square.

Have students write these words in sequence, using the clues.
Add ly to dear to make a word that means greatly, very much.
Change one letter in dearly to make a word that means every year.
Change one letter in yearly to make a word that means almost.
Replace ar in nearly with one letter to make a word that means recently, just now.
Change two letters in newly to make a word that means more new.

In Hmong, adverbs do not exist. Instead, two adjectives or two verbs are used (e.g., I ran fast fast to the store). In Spanish, Arabic, Farsi, Vietnamese, and Hmong, adjectives follow the nouns they modify (instead of before the noun, as in English).

In Hmong, adverbs do not exist. Instead, two adjectives or two verbs are used (e.g., I ran fast fast to the store). In Spanish, Arabic, Farsi, Vietnamese, and Hmong, adjectives follow the nouns they modify (instead of before the noun, as in English).

Practice articulation with a few simple sentences containing adjectives and adverbs, such as: The happy dog wagged its tail. and I ran quickly. Then have students copy the sentences to practice writing the sentences in correct English word order.
